parse.title: List of places visited by Ibn Battuta

text.*:
This is a List of places visited by Ibn Battuta in the years 1325-1353.

The Moroccan traveller Ibn Battuta set out from his native town of Tangiers on a pilgrimage to Mecca in June 1325, when he was 21 years old. On completing his first hajj he continued travelling, only returning to Morocco twenty four years later in 1349. In 1350, Battuta visited Al-Andalus and then between 1352-1353 he crossed the Sahara Desert to visit the Kingdom of Mali in West Africa. On his return to Fes he dictated an account of his travels to Ibn Juzayy, a scribe employed by Abu Inan Faris, the Marinid ruler of Morocco.[1]

Ibn Juzayy's Arabic text was translated into English by Hamilton Gibb and Charles Beckingham and published by the Hakluyt Society in four volumes between 1958 and 1994.[2]

Contents

  • 1 Places visited by Ibn Battuta
    • 1.1 Maghreb
    • 1.2 Arab Mashriq
    • 1.3 Arabian Peninsula
    • 1.4 Persia and Iraq
    • 1.5 East Africa
    • 1.6 Anatolia
    • 1.7 Central Asia
    • 1.8 South Asia
    • 1.9 China
    • 1.10 Southeast Asia
    • 1.11 Al-Andalus
    • 1.12 Mali Empire and West Africa
    • 1.13 Itinerary 1325–1332
    • 1.14 Itinerary 1332–1346
    • 1.15 Itinerary 1349–1353
  • 2 References
  • 3 Sources

Places visited by Ibn Battuta[edit]

Over his lifetime, Ibn Battuta travelled over 73,000 miles (117,000 km) and visited around 40 present-day countries.[3]

In the following list the Romanization used by Gibb and Beckingham is given in parentheses. The states are modern. Within each section the towns are listed in the order that they are first mentioned in Ibn Battuta's rihla. Historians such as Hamilton Gibb and Ross Dunn have argued that some parts of Ibn Battuta's rihla are fictional and it is extremely unlikely that he visited all the places that he claimed. The cities for which Ibn Battuta's visit is believed to be fictional are flagged as "doubtful" in the list below.

Maghreb[edit]

  • Tangier, Morocco[4]
  • Tlemcen (Tilimsān), Algeria[5]
  • Miliana (Milyāna), Algeria[6]
  • Algiers (al-Jazā'ir), Algeria[6]
  • Béjaïa (Bijāya), Algeria[6]
  • Constantine (Qusanṭīna), Algeria[7]
  • Annaba (Būna), Algeria[7]
  • Tunis, Tunisia[7]
  • Sousse (Sūsa), Tunisia[8]
  • Sfax (Ṣafāqus), Tunisia[8]
  • Gabès (Qābis), Tunisia[9]
  • Tripoli (Aṭrābulus), Libya[10]
  • Taza (Tāzā), Morocco[11]
  • Fes (Fās), Morocco[11]
  • Ceuta (Sabta), Spain[12]
  • Marrakech (Marrākush), Morocco[13]
  • Salé (Salā), Morocco[13]
  • Meknes (Miknāsa), Morocco[14]
  • Sijilmasa (Sijilmāsa), Morocco[14]

Arab Mashriq[edit]

  • Alexandria (al-Iskandarīya), Egypt[15]
  • Damanhur (Damanhūr), Egypt[16]
  • Fuwwah (Fawwā), Egypt[16]
  • Ibyar (Abyār), Egypt[17] 30°50′20″N 30°51′50″E﻿ / ﻿30.839°N 30.864°E﻿ / 30.839; 30.864
  • El-Mahalla El-Kubra (al-Maḥalla al-Kabīra), Egypt[18]
  • Damietta (Dimyāt), Egypt[19]
  • Faraskur (Fāriskūr), Egypt[20]
  • Sebennytos or Samannoud (Samannūd), Egypt[20]
  • Cairo (Miṣr), Egypt[21]
  • Biba (Biba), Egypt[22] 28°55′19″N 30°59′02″E﻿ / ﻿28.922°N 30.984°E﻿ / 28.922; 30.984
  • Oxyrhynchus (al-Bahnasa), Egypt[22]
  • Minya (Munyat Ibn Khaṣīb), Egypt[22]
  • Mallawi (Manlāwī), Egypt[23]
  • Manfalut (Manfalūṭ), Egypt[24]
  • Asyut (Asyūṭ), Egypt[24]
  • Akhmim (Ikhmīm), Egypt[25]
  • Hu (Hū), Egypt[26]
  • Qena (Qinā), Egypt[26]
  • Qus (Qūṣ), Egypt[26]
  • Luxor (al-Aqṣur), Egypt[27]
  • Esna (Asnā), Egypt[27]
  • Edfu (Adfū), Egypt[28]
  • ‘Aydhab (‘Aidhāb), Egypt[28]
  • Bilbeis (Balbais), Egypt[29]
  • Gaza (Ghazza), Gaza Strip[30]
  • Hebron (al-Khalīl), West Bank[30]
  • Bethlehem (Bait Laḥm), West Bank[31]
  • Jerusalem (al-Quds)[31]
  • Ramla (al-Ramla), Israel[32]
  • Nablus (Nābulus ), West Bank[32]
  • Ajloun (‘Ajlun), Jordan[32]
  • Tyre (Sūr), Lebanon[33]
  • Sidon (Ṣaidā), Lebanon[34]
  • Tripoli (Aṭrābulus), Lebanon[35]
  • Hama (Ḥamāh), Syria[36]
  • Aleppo (Ḥalab), Syria[37]
  • Antioch (Antākiya), Turkey[38]
  • Bagras (Bughrās), Turkey[39]
  • Latakia (al-Lādhiqīya), Syria[40]
  • Baalbek (Ba‘labakk), Lebanon[41]
  • Damascus, Syria[42]
  • Al-Kiswah (al-Kiswa), Syria[43]
  • Al Karak (Al-Karak), Jordon[44]
  • Ma'an (Ma‘ān), Jordon[45]

Arabian Peninsula[edit]

  • Tabuk (Tabūk), Saudi Arabia[45]
  • Medina (al-Madīna), Saudi Arabia[46]
  • Rabigh (Rābigh), Saudi Arabia[47]
  • Mecca, Saudi Arabia[48]
  • Jeddah (Judda), Saudi Arabia[49]
  • Zabīd (Zabīd), Yemen[50]
  • Jibla (Jubla), Yemen[51]
  • Ta'izz (Ta'izz), Yemen[52]
  • Sana'a (Ṣan'ā'), Yemen[53] Doubtful.[54]
  • Aden ('Adan), Yemen[53]
  • Salalah (Zafāri), Oman[55]
  • Qalhat (Qalhāt), Oman[56]
  • Nizwa (Nazwā), Oman[57]
  • Bahrain (al-Baḥrain), Bahrain[58] Adjacent shore.
  • Qatif (al-Quṭaif), Saudi Arabia[59]
  • Hofuf or al-Hasa (Hajar), Saudi Arabia[59]
  • Al-Yamama (al-Yamama), Saudi Arabia[59] 24°07′N 47°25′E﻿ / ﻿24.117°N 47.417°E﻿ / 24.117; 47.417

Persia and Iraq[edit]

  • Najaf (al-Najaf), Iraq[60]
  • Basra (al-Basra), Iraq[61]
  • Abadan ('Abbādān), Iran[62]
  • Bandar-e Mahshahr (Māchūl), Iran[63]
  • Ramhormoz (Rāmiz), Iran[63]
  • Shushtar (Tustar), Iran[64]
  • Izeh (Īdhaj), Iran[65]
  • Isfahan (Iṣfahān), Iran[66]
  • Shiraz (Shīrāz), Iran[67]
  • Kazerun (Kāzarūn), Iran[68]
  • Kufa (al-Kūfa), Iraq[69]
  • Hillah (al-Ḥilla), Iraq[70]
  • Baghdad (Baghdād), Iraq[71]
  • Tabriz (Tabrīz), Iran[72]
  • Mosul (al-Mawṣil), Iraq[73]
  • Cizre (Jazīrat Ibn 'Omar), Turkey[74]
  • Sinjar (Sinjār), Iraq[75]
  • Mardin (Mārdīn), Turkey[75]
  • Hormuz (New Hurmuz), Iran[76]
  • Lar (Lār), Iran[77]

East Africa[edit]

  • Suakin (Sawākin), Sudan[78]
  • Zeila (Zaila'), Somalia[79]
  • Mogadishu (Maqdashaw), Somalia[80]
  • Mombasa (Mambasā), Kenya[81]
  • Kilwa (Kulwā), Tanzania[81]

Anatolia[edit]

  • Alanya (al-‘Alāyā), Turkey[82]
  • Antalya (Anṭāliya), Turkey[82]
  • Burdur (Burdūr), Turkey[83]
  • Isparta (Sabartā), Turkey[84]
  • Eğirdir (Akrīdūr), Turkey[84]
  • Gölhisar (Qul-Ḥiṣār), Turkey[85]
  • Laodicea on the Lycus near Denizli (Lādhiq), Turkey[86]
  • Tavas (Ṭawās), Turkey[87]
  • Muğla (Mughla), Turkey[87]
  • Milas (Mīlās), Turkey[87]
  • Konya (Qūniya), Turkey[88]
  • Karaman (al-Lāranda), Turkey[89]
  • Aksaray (Aqsarā), Turkey[90]
  • Niğde (Nakda), Turkey[91]
  • Kayseri (Qaisarīya), Turkey[91]
  • Sivas (Sīwās), Turkey[92]
  • Amasya (Amāṣiya), Turkey[93]
  • Uluköy (Sūnusā), Turkey[93]
  • Gümüşhane (Kumish), Turkey[93]
  • Erzincan (Arzananjān), Turkey[94]
  • Erzurum (Arz al-Rūm), Turkey[94]
  • Birgi (Birgī), Turkey[95]
  • Tire (Tīra), Turkey[96]
  • Selçuk (Ayā Sulūq), Turkey[96]
  • İzmir (Yazmir), Turkey[97]
  • Manisa (Maghnīsīya), Turkey[98]
  • Bergama (Barghama), Turkey[99]
  • Balıkesir (Balī Kasrī), Turkey[100]
  • Bursa (Burṣā), Turkey[100]
  • İznik (Yasnīk), Turkey[101]
  • Geyve (Kāwiya), Turkey[102]
  • Taraklı (Yanijā), Turkey[103]
  • Göynük (Kainūk), Turkey[104]
  • Mudurnu (Maṭurnī), Turkey[104]
  • Bolu (Būlī), Turkey[105]
  • Gerede (Garadai), Turkey[106]
  • Safranbolu (Burlū), Turkey[107]
  • Kastamonu (Qaṣṭamūniya), Turkey[107]
  • Sinop (Ṣanūb), Turkey[108]
  • Constantinople, Turkey[109]

Central Asia[edit]

  • Feodosia (al-Kafā), Ukraine/Russia[110]
  • Stary Krym (al-Qiram), Ukraine/Russia[111]
  • Azov (Azāk), Russia[112]
  • Majar (al-Māchar), Russia[113]
  • Pyatigorsk (Bish Dagh), Russia[114]
  • Bolghar (Bulghār), Russia[115] Very doubtful.[116]
  • Astrakhan (al-Ḥājj Tarhān), Russia[117]
  • New Sarai (al-Sarā), Russia[118]
  • Sarayshyk (Sarāchūq), Kazakhstan[119]
  • Konye-Urgench (Khwārizm), Turkmenistan[120]
  • Bukhara (Bukhārā), Uzbekistan[121]
  • Qarshi (Nakhshab), Uzbekistan[122]
  • Samarkand (Samarqand), Uzbekistan[123]
  • Termez (Tirmidh), Uzbekistan[124]
  • Balkh (Balkh), Afghanistan[125]
  • Herat (Harāt), Afghanistan[126] Doubtful.[127][128]
  • Torbat-e Jam (al-Jām), Iran[129] Doubtful.[127][128]
  • Tus (Ṭūs), Iran[130] Doubtful.[127][128]
  • Nishapur(Naisābūr), Iran[131] Doubtful.[127][128]
  • Bastam (Bisṭām), Iran[132] Doubtful.[127][128]
  • Kunduz (Qundūz), Afghanistan[132]
  • Ghazni (Ghazna), Afghanistan[133]
  • Kabul (Kābul), Afghanistan[134]

South Asia[edit]

  • Uch (Ūja), Pakistan[135]
  • Multan (Multān), Pakistan[135]
  • Abohar (Abūhar), India[136]
  • Pakpattan (Ajudahan), Pakistan[137]
  • Sirsa (Sarasatī), India[138]
  • Hansi (Ḥānsī), India[138]
  • Delhi (Dihlī), India[139]
  • Aligarh (Kuwil), India[140]
  • Kannauj (Qinauj), India[141]
  • Gwalior (Guyālyur), India[142]
  • Ujjain (Ujain), India[143]
  • Daulatabad (Dawlat Ābād), India[143]
  • Khambhat or Cambay (Kinbāya), India[144]
  • Gandhar (Qandahār), India[145] 21°53′13″N 72°39′29″E﻿ / ﻿21.887°N 72.658°E﻿ / 21.887; 72.658
  • Honnavar (Hinawr), India[146]
  • Mangalore (Manjarūr), India[147]
  • Kannur or Cannanore, India[148]
  • Kozhikode or Calicut (Qāliqūt), India[149]
  • Kollam or Quilon (Kawlam), India[150]
  • Malé (Mahal), Maldives[151]
  • Puttalam (Baṭṭāla), Sri Lanka[152]
  • Adam's Peak (Sarandīb), Sri Lanka[153]
  • Dondra Head (Dīnawar), Sri Lanka[154]
  • Chittagong, Bangladesh or possibly Satgaon, India (Sudkāwān)[155] Identification of Sudkāwān uncertain.[156]
  • Sonargaon (Sunarkāwān), Bangladesh[157]

China[edit]

  • Quanzhou (Zaitūn), China[158]
  • Guangzhou or Canton (Ṣīn al-Ṣīn), China[159]
  • Fuzhou? (Qanjanfū), China[160] Uncertain.[161]
  • Hangzhou (al-Khansā), China[162] Doubtful.[163]
  • Beijing (Khān Bāliq), China[164] Doubtful.[165]

Southeast Asia[edit]

  • Samudera Pasai Sultanate (Sumuṭra), Northern Sumatra, Indonesia[166] Exact location uncertain.[167]

Al-Andalus[edit]

  • Gibraltar (Mountain of Victory), United Kingdom[12]
  • Ronda (Runda), Spain[168]
  • Marbella (Marbala), Spain[168]
  • Málaga (Málaga), Spain[169]
  • Granada (Gharnāṭa), Spain[170]

Mali Empire and West Africa[edit]

  • Taghaza (Taghāzā), Mali[14]
  • Oualata (Īwālātan), Mauritania[171]
  • Timbuktu (Tunbuktū), Mali[172]
  • Gao (Kaukau), Mali[173]
  • Takedda (Takaddā), Niger[174]
  • Tuat (Tawāt), Algeria[175]
